item.title: ​Longevity drugs for dogs help humans too - The Times of India
item.description:
Longevity Drugs for Dogs Help Humans Too

Publication Date: Not provided | Source: Not specified

Recent studies suggest that longevity drugs developed for canines may also have significant benefits for human health. This breakthrough highlights the interconnectedness of veterinary and human medical research.

  • Research indicates that compounds used in dog longevity treatments may enhance human healthspan.
  • The findings bring new perspectives on aging and disease prevention in humans.
  • Veterinary advancements often contribute to significant strides in human medicine.
"The implications of this research could change the way we approach aging in both dogs and humans alike."

This intersection of veterinary and human health science continues to offer exciting possibilities for combating aging and improving life quality across species.

item.title: Emergence of coinfection with visceral Leishmania infantum in COVID-19 patients: a case‒control field study in an endemic area of visceral leishmaniasis in Iran - BMC Infectious Diseases
item.description:
Emergence of Coinfection with Visceral Leishmania infantum in COVID-19 Patients: A Case-Control Field Study in an Endemic Area of Visceral Leishmaniasis in Iran

Published: 30 December 2024 | Source: BMC Infectious Diseases

This study examines the prevalence of Leishmania infantum coinfection in COVID-19 patients in a site endemic to visceral leishmaniasis in Iran.

  • 250 blood samples from hospitalized COVID-19 patients and 231 from a control group were analyzed.
  • 18.4% of COVID-19 patients tested positive for L. infantum, compared to 7.8% in the control group.
  • COVID-19 patients had a 2.66 times greater chance of having L. infantum infection.
  • No significant association was found between L. infantum infection and various patient demographics or treatment outcomes.
"The overall seroprevalence of L. infantum infection among patients with COVID-19 was 2.66 times greater than that in the control group."

This study emphasizes the potential risk factor of L. infantum infection in COVID-19 patients, particularly in endemic areas.

item.title: Weight-Loss Drugs, Wily Viruses, Abortion Pill Under Attack: The Top Health Stories of 2024 - HealthDay
item.description:
Weight-Loss Drugs, Wily Viruses, Abortion Pill Under Attack: The Top Health Stories of 2024

Date: December 30, 2024 | Source: HealthDay News

This year in health news presented significant advancements alongside formidable challenges, including the impact of weight-loss drugs, emerging viral threats, and contentious debates over abortion pill access.

  • GLP-1 weight-loss drugs, like Ozempic, led to a slight decline in obesity rates in the U.S.
  • Bird flu (H5N1) outbreaks affected over 900 dairy herds, raising public health concerns.
  • Severe mpox variants emerged, prompting a WHO declaration of a public health emergency.
  • Access to abortion pills has been hotly contested in conservative states since the overturning of Roe v. Wade.
  • The incoming Trump administration is expected to challenge longstanding public health policies.
“The last year suggests [GLP-1 drugs] could change the health landscape as much as cholesterol-lowering medications did when they were first introduced.”

As 2025 approaches, the landscape of public health remains uncertain, with ongoing debates likely to shape future policy and people's health.

item.title: Most of 2024’s dengue cases in Goa were detected in non-monsoon period - The Times of India
item.description:
Dengue Cases in Goa Rise During Non-Monsoon Season in 2024

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Times of India

Goa has seen a significant number of dengue cases in the year 2024, predominantly occurring outside the typical monsoon season, raising concerns among health officials.

  • The majority of dengue cases were reported from January to May.
  • Health officials are investigating the unusual seasonal trend.
  • Local health services are preparing for potential outbreaks as winter approaches.
“We are monitoring the situation closely to avoid larger outbreaks.” - State health official

This shift in dengue patterns could indicate changing climate conditions and necessitates ongoing public health vigilance.

item.title: Five years on, WHO urges China to share Covid origins data - Firstpost
item.description:
WHO Calls on China for Covid Origins Data After Five Years

Publication Date: Monday

Source: Reuters

Five years after the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic, the World Health Organization (WHO) is urging China to share crucial data related to the origins of the virus.

  • The WHO emphasizes the need for transparency and cooperation to prevent future pandemics.
  • Covid-19 has had devastating effects globally, resulting in millions of deaths and economic turmoil.
  • The WHO recalled how it first learned of the viral pneumonia cases in Wuhan, which marked the onset of the pandemic.
  • WHO Director General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus indicates that while the world has improved its pandemic preparedness, vulnerabilities still persist.
  • Negotiations for a global accord on pandemic prevention are ongoing, with challenges related to equity between wealthy and poorer nations.
“Without transparency, sharing, and cooperation among countries, the world cannot adequately prevent and prepare for future epidemics and pandemics.” - WHO Statement

The WHO's call for cooperation and data sharing highlights the ongoing importance of understanding Covid-19's origins to prepare for future health crises.

item.title: Big breakthrough in medical treatment: Korean scientists find undo button that turns tumour cells into nor - The Economic Times
item.description:
Korean Scientists Discover Method to Turn Tumor Cells into Normal Cells

Publication Date: December 30, 2024 | Source: The Feed

This groundbreaking study from KAIST reveals a new approach to cancer treatment, focusing on converting colon cancer cells into normal cells instead of destroying them.

  • KAIST researchers have developed technology that transforms colon cancer cells back into normal cells.
  • This method minimizes side effects and reduces the likelihood of cancer recurrence.
  • Professor Kwang-Hyun Cho leads the project, offering a significant shift from traditional cancer treatments.
  • The research utilized a digital twin of the gene network to identify key molecular switches in cells.
  • The findings could pave the way for new cancer therapies that are safer and more effective.
“The ability of cancer cells to transform back into healthy cells is a remarkable phenomenon. This study demonstrates that it is possible to systematically induce such reversion.” - Professor Kwang-Hyun Cho

This innovative approach to treating cancer signifies a major breakthrough, potentially changing how the disease is approached in the future.

item.title: Dangers of too much sitting: Why it can harm you even if you exercise; study explains - The Times of India
item.description:
Dangers of too much sitting: Why it can harm you even if you exercise; study explains

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Times of India

This article discusses the findings of a recent study that reveals the harmful effects of prolonged sitting, even for those who regularly exercise.

  • The study highlights how sedentary behavior increases the risk of certain health issues.
  • It emphasizes the importance of incorporating movement throughout the day.
  • The research suggests that the negative effects of sitting cannot be entirely offset by exercise.
"Sitting for extended periods is detrimental to health, regardless of exercise habits."

The findings serve as a reminder for individuals to remain active throughout their daily routines to mitigate potential health risks.

item.title: When chikungunya found a permanent place in Mumbai... - The Times of India
item.description:
When Chikungunya Found a Permanent Place in Mumbai

Publication Date: Unknown | Source: Unknown

This article discusses the persistent presence of the chikungunya virus in Mumbai, its impact on the population, and ongoing public health challenges.

  • Chikungunya has established itself permanently in Mumbai.
  • Cases of chikungunya are increasing during monsoon seasons.
  • The local healthcare system is facing challenges in managing the outbreak.
  • Public awareness and preventive measures are crucial in controlling the spread.
"The virus has become an enduring issue for public health in the city."

The ongoing presence of chikungunya in Mumbai highlights the importance of sustained public health efforts to manage mosquito-borne diseases.

item.title: Odds of Metabolic Disease Lower With Fast Subjective Walking Speed in Patients With Obesity - HealthDay
item.description:
Odds of Metabolic Disease Lower With Fast Subjective Walking Speed in Patients With Obesity

Date: Dec. 30, 2024 | Source: HealthDay News

This study indicates that a faster subjective walking speed correlates with a reduced risk of metabolic diseases in individuals with obesity.

  • Study published in Scientific Reports on Nov. 15.
  • Examined 8,578 individuals with a BMI ≥25.0 kg/m2.
  • Found a risk ratio of 0.70 for diabetes mellitus in individuals with obesity and fast walking speed.
  • Different risk ratios highlighted for various metabolic diseases based on waist circumference and BMI.
"This study revealed that even in those with obesity, who have a higher risk of metabolic diseases, a fast subjective walking speed was associated with lower odds of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and dyslipidemia."

The findings suggest that encouraging faster walking could play a significant role in reducing the prevalence of metabolic diseases among obese individuals.

item.title: Microplastics found in multiple human organ tissues correlated with lesions - Phys.org
item.description:
Microplastics Found in Multiple Human Organ Tissues Correlated with Lesions

Publication Date: 30 December 2024 | Source: Science X Network

Research indicates concerning correlations between microplastics in human tissues and various health conditions, highlighting the widespread impact of plastic pollution.

  • Study led by Zhejiang Agriculture and Forestry University performed a metadata investigation into microplastics in humans.
  • Established links between microplastics and health conditions, noting concentrations were higher in damaged tissues.
  • Microplastics present in diverse human organs, including skin, lungs, and reproductive systems.
  • Calls for reliable methods to assess risks and mitigation measures for microplastic exposure.
"Measured levels of microplastics tended to be higher in tissues with lesions than in non-lesioned tissues, suggesting a potential link between MNP buildup and local pathology."

Further research is needed to explore the causal relationships between microplastic accumulation and health impacts.

item.title: UK Announces Dengue Vaccine For Travellers, To Be Prescribed Only For Those With A Previous Infection - ABP Live
item.description:
UK Launches Dengue Vaccine for Travelers with Previous Infections

Publication Date: 2023

Source: ABP News

The UK has approved a new dengue vaccine named Qdenga for travelers heading to endemic countries, but it will only be prescribed to those with a prior dengue infection. This decision comes as dengue fever cases rise globally, impacting half of the world's population.

  • The live attenuated tetravalent dengue vaccine, Qdenga, was licensed in the UK in 2023.
  • With climate change and urbanization, dengue spread has extended beyond traditional regions, including parts of Europe.
  • Qdenga requires two doses administered three months apart for effective immunization.
  • It is contraindicated for pregnant and breastfeeding women and those with compromised immunity.
  • Health officials have emphasized the importance of combining vaccination with mosquito bite prevention.
“Since no specific treatments exist for dengue virus infection, prevention is paramount.”

The introduction of Qdenga represents a significant step in dengue prevention, crucial for travelers and those living in endemic regions.

item.title: Every cigarette takes 17 minutes off life expectancy in men, 22 in women: Study - The Times of India
item.description:
Every cigarette takes 17 minutes off life expectancy in men, 22 in women: Study

Publication Date: 2023-10-02 Source: Study Findings

This study highlights the significant impact of smoking on life expectancy, revealing that each cigarette reduces life expectancy by an average of 17 minutes for men and 22 minutes for women.

  • The average life lost due to each cigarette is alarming, emphasizing the health risks associated with smoking.
  • The gender disparity in life expectancy reduction indicates different health impacts based on sex.
  • The study calls for increased public health awareness and smoking cessation programs.
“Every cigarette smoked is a step towards a shorter life.”

In conclusion, this study serves as a stark reminder of the dangers of smoking and the need for health policies aimed at reducing tobacco consumption.

item.title: Milestone: COVID-19 five years ago - World Health Organization
item.description:
Milestone: COVID-19 five years ago

Publication Date: 31 December 2024 Source: WHO Media Team

Five years ago on 31 December 2019, WHO’s Country Office in China picked up a media statement by the Wuhan Municipal Health Commission about 'viral pneumonia' cases in Wuhan, which led to the emergence of COVID-19 and its profound impact on global lives.

  • WHO activated emergency systems on 1 January 2020 and informed the world on 4 January.
  • The first comprehensive guidance was published by WHO between 9-12 January 2020.
  • On 13 January, WHO collaborated with partners to develop the first SARS-CoV-2 laboratory test.
  • As we take this milestone moment, we honor those who suffered and died, and express gratitude to healthcare workers.
  • WHO continues to urge China to share data on COVID-19's origins, vital for future preparedness.
“Is the world better prepared for the next pandemic than we were for COVID-19?” - Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus

As we reflect on the past five years, we emphasize the lessons learned to build a healthier future and ensure better preparedness for potential pandemics.

item.title: 10 micro-resolutions you can achieve in 10 minutes or less this New Year 2025 - The Times of India
item.description:
10 Micro-Resolutions You Can Achieve in 10 Minutes or Less This New Year 2025

Publication Date: December 31, 2024 • Source: Times of India

As the New Year approaches, focusing on small, manageable changes can lead to more lasting results than traditional, grand resolutions. Here are ten micro-resolutions that can each be accomplished in ten minutes or less.

  • 10 Minutes of Walk

    Start your day with a brisk ten-minute walk to boost heart health and lifespan.

  • 9 Minutes of Reading

    Enhance memory and reduce stress through a quick reading session.

  • 8 Minutes of Preparing a Healthy Snack

    Start your day with a nutritious breakfast incorporating all food groups.

  • 7 Minutes of Stretching

    Relieve stress and prevent injury by taking a few minutes to stretch.

  • 6 Minutes of Journal Writing

    Enhance self-awareness and clarity by writing in a journal.

  • 5 Minutes of Meditation

    Boost focus and productivity through a short meditation session.

  • 4 Minutes of Planning

    Quickly plan your day to improve organization and clarity.

  • 3 Minutes of Decluttering Space

    Prepare for your workday with a tidy workspace.

  • 2 Minutes of Deep Breathing

    Calm your mind and reduce anxiety through deep breathing exercises.

  • Take a Minute to Drink a Glass of Water

    Stay hydrated to improve health and focus.
Each of these 10 goals requires no more than 10 minutes of your time and sets the stage for greater achievements in the New Year.

By adopting these micro-resolutions, you can make meaningful changes that promote wellness and prepare you for larger goals in 2025.

item.title: Quit smoking on New Year! One cigarette takes 20 minutes off a person’s life - The Week
item.description:
Quit Smoking on New Year! One Cigarette Takes 20 Minutes Off a Person’s Life

Publication Date: January 1, 2023 Source: The Guardian

As the New Year approaches, smokers are encouraged to quit their habit, with a new study indicating the severe impact of smoking on life expectancy.

  • Smoking reduces life expectancy by about 20 minutes per cigarette.
  • A pack of 20 cigarettes can shorten life by nearly 7 hours.
  • Quitting on January 1 could lead to significant life gains.
  • Smokers who quit could avoid losing 50 days of life by year-end.
  • Smoking causes over 7 million deaths annually worldwide.
“On average, smokers who don’t quit lose around a decade of life. That’s 10 years of precious time, life moments, and milestones with loved ones.” - Dr. Sarah Jackson

The research highlights the dire health risks associated with smoking and encourages smokers to take action for a healthier future.

item.title: The War Against AMR - Centre for Science and Environment
item.description:
The War Against AMR

Date: December 30, 2024

Source: Down to Earth

This series of expert articles focuses on antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in recognition of World AMR Awareness Week 2024, exploring challenges and solutions across various sectors.

  • The compendium features contributions from global and Indian experts.
  • It addresses different aspects of AMR, including policy, practice, and technology.
  • The theme of the articles is 'Prevent AMR'.
  • Originally published in Down to Earth's web version during WAAW 2024.
The overarching theme is to prevent AMR through collaborative efforts across One Health sectors.

The articles collectively stress the urgency of tackling AMR and implementing the National Action Plan effectively.

item.title: Mediterranean To DASH Diet: Top 7 Healthy Diets You Must Try In 2025 - Times Now
item.description:
Mediterranean To DASH Diet: Top 7 Healthy Diets You Must Try In 2025

Publication Date: 2025   |   Source: Times Now

This article presents seven healthy diets that are popular and effective for 2025, providing insights into their benefits and expert recommendations.

  • Mediterranean Diet: Focuses on fresh produce, whole grains, and healthy fats. Supports heart health.
  • Plant-Based Diet: Emphasizes vegetables and legumes. Linked to reduced risk of type 2 diabetes.
  • Flexitarian Diet: A flexible mix of plant-based and occasional animal products. Sustainable and balanced.
  • DASH Diet: Reduces high blood pressure through potassium-rich foods. Supported by research for heart health.
  • Nordic Diet: Rich in whole grains and fatty fish. Promotes heart health and reduces inflammation.
  • Intermittent Fasting (IF): Focuses on meal timing. Aids in weight management and metabolic health.
  • Probiotic-Rich Diet: Includes foods like yogurt and kimchi. Supports gut health and immunity.

To get started, choose a diet that fits your lifestyle, consult with a nutrition professional, make gradual changes, and stay consistent.

item.title: Influenza Vaccine Effective Against Severe Illness in Children - Clinical Advisor
item.description:
Influenza Vaccine Effective Against Severe Illness in Children

Date: Published on JAMA Network Open

Source: HealthDay News

The influenza vaccine is reported to be effective in preventing severe illness among children based on a study conducted by the CDC. The research involved over 15,000 children and showed that vaccination significantly helps reduce hospital visits due to influenza.

  • The study analyzed data from 8 medical centers across different states.
  • Out of 15,728 children, 2710 tested positive for influenza.
  • Vaccination was associated with a 55.7% effectiveness in preventing emergency department visits or hospitalizations.
  • The effectiveness was consistent across different illness severity levels.
  • Improving vaccine uptake is emphasized as crucial for reducing influenza complications.
“Vaccination is one of the most effective ways to protect children against influenza and its complications, including severe illness and hospitalization.”

This study underscores the importance of influenza vaccination to protect children and optimize healthcare resources during peak respiratory virus seasons.

item.title: How can we manage stress from bossy bosses and deadlines? | Health Wealth, Ep 76 - India Today Podcast
item.description:
How can we manage stress from bossy bosses and deadlines? | Health Wealth, Ep 76

Publication Date: N/A Source: Health Wealth

This episode discusses the rise of work-related stress in the 21st century, exploring whether we are solving these stressors or simply becoming more obsessed with them. Integrative lifestyle medicine expert Luke Coutinho shares actionable solutions to improve our ability to handle workplace challenges.

  • Work-related stress may have increased due to modern demands.
  • Luke Coutinho's six pillars for wellness can mitigate stress.
  • Adjustments in diet, exercise, sleep, and emotional health are crucial.
  • Work should enhance, not govern, our happiness and peace of mind.
“Ensure work remains a part of life, not the governor of your happiness and peace of mind.”

Tune in to gain insights into managing stress effectively.

item.title: Weight loss at home: Simple exercises to shed pounds and keep active this winter - The Times of India
item.description:
Weight Loss at Home: Simple Exercises to Shed Pounds and Keep Active This Winter

Publication Date: Unknown Source: Unknown

This article provides readers with effective and simple exercises they can do at home to aid in weight loss and maintain their fitness levels during the winter months.

  • Focuses on easy-to-follow home workouts.
  • Encourages physical activity to combat winter lethargy.
  • Highlights the benefits of staying active for mental and physical health.
“Staying active during the winter is crucial for both physical and mental well-being.”

The article emphasizes the importance of creating a consistent workout routine even when the weather outside is not conducive to outdoor activities.

item.title: FDA approves lenacapavir for HIV treatment; Science journal hails it as 'breakthrough of the year' - The New Indian Express
item.description:
FDA Approves Lenacapavir for HIV Treatment; Science Journal Hails it as 'Breakthrough of the Year'

Publication Date: 30 Dec 2024
Source: AP

The FDA has approved Lenacapavir, an injectable drug that protects against HIV for six months with each dose, which has been recognized by Science journal as a major breakthrough in combating the HIV/AIDS crisis.

  • Lenacapavir provides long-term protection against HIV with biannual injections.
  • Science journal labeled it 'breakthrough of the year' for its efficacy in HIV prevention.
  • Clinical trials showed 100% efficacy among African adolescent girls and 99.9% among gender-diverse populations.
  • HOPE for reducing global HIV infections relies on access and demand for the drug.
"It has the potential if we can do it right, which means going big and getting it out there." - Linda-Gail Bekker, University of Cape Town

Lenacapavir represents a significant advancement in HIV prevention, with the potential to transform public health efforts against the epidemic.

item.title: Sick kids and cold season blues: Ultimate guide for parents to prevent dehydration in children - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Boosting Kids' Immunity: A Parent's Guide to Preventing Dehydration During Illness

Date & Source: Published on HT Lifestyle

Introduction: Seasonal changes often bring fluctuating weather conditions and an increased risk of illnesses in children, which can lead to dehydration and reduced energy levels.

  1. Dehydration and its impact on immunity: Pediatric expert Dr. NL Sridhar explains that dehydration can weaken children's immunity and leave them more vulnerable to infections.
  2. How seasonal illnesses lead to dehydration: Fever, nausea, and vomiting are common in children during seasonal changes and can result in fluid, electrolyte, and energy deficits.
  3. Highlighting the role of fluid, electrolyte, and energy (FEE) deficits in supporting recovery: Dr. NL Sridhar emphasizes the importance of replenishing fluids, electrolytes, and energy to counteract the effects of dehydration.
  4. The Role of Electrolytes in Recovery: Electrolytes like sodium, potassium, and magnesium are vital for recovery during seasonal illnesses.
  5. The Importance of Timely Intervention: Early identification and management of dehydration and energy deficits can significantly improve recovery in children.
Notable Quote: "Ready-to-drink formulations with a scientifically balanced composition of electrolytes and energy are particularly beneficial as they ensure consistent quality and taste." - Dr. NL Sridhar

Conclusion: Parents should remain vigilant for signs of dehydration and consult pediatricians for appropriate care, prioritizing hydration and addressing energy needs to help children navigate seasonal transitions with resilience and good health.

Disclaimer: The information provided in this article are scientific facts only and not a substitute for any professional advice. Please consult a doctor / nutritionist for more information on managing dehydration during infections.
